title: Cat. 3  Calf’s Head and Ox Tongue, c. 1882
publication_title: Caillebotte Paintings and Drawings at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Calf’s Head and Ox Tongue  
c. 1882  
Oil on canvas; 73 × 54 cm (28 1/2 × 21 1/4 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Major Acquisitions Centennial Endowment, 1999.561

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Calf’s Head and Ox Tongue is one of four related paintings showing raw meat, depicted either sitting on a countertop (fig. 3.1 [Berhaut 1978, no. 223; Berhaut 1994, no. 245]) or, in the two more elaborate compositions, hanging on metal hooks or wooden hangers (fig. 3.2 [Berhaut 1978, no. 221; Berhaut 1994, no. 243] and fig. 3.3 [Berhaut 1978, no. 220; Berhaut 1994, no. 242]). None of these are signed or dated, although all but this one bear an estate stamp resembling a signature. None were exhibited or sold during the artist’s lifetime, and, until the Art Institute’s purchase in 1999, all remained in the family collection (see Provenance and Exhibition History). Some critics, like Joris-Karl Huysmans, made special note of Caillebotte’s still-life paintings, yet they were less known than his cityscapes and interior views. And still lifes with a focus solely on raw meat are rarer still, with few narrative clues to help the viewer understand these jarring but exquisitely painted cuts of meat.

These paintings are thought to have been conceived after the seventh Impressionist exhibition in 1882, where Caillebotte showed paintings depicting modern life, and land and riverscapes at Trouville. The exhibition also included the startling still life Fruit Displayed on a Stand (fig. 3.4 [Berhaut 1978, no. 178; Berhaut 1994, no. 193]). Huysmans described the scene as “extraordinary . . . this is conveyed with strict truthfulness, an absolute fidelity of tone.” This veristic slice of life was unprecedented not only in Caillebotte’s oeuvre, but also within the genre in general, causing Huysmans to further observe, “This is still life freed from its routine.” In addition to its originality, this commissioned work was both decorative and appealing, whereas the meat paintings were radically disconcerting and uncommercial, focusing on a subject for experimentation rather than exhibition or sale.

In Fruit Displayed on a Stand, Caillebotte focused not only on the precisely arranged fruits, but also on how they were staged in “white paper beds” (as Huysmans described them) by an upscale shopkeeper for the delectation of the viewer-consumer. Likewise, in the two largest paintings of meat, Calf in a Butcher’s Shop and Display of Chickens and Game Birds, the artist presents the way in which meat was displayed commercially, between the slaughterhouse and the bourgeois table. Within the still-life pictures that depict meat of various kinds, Caillebotte distinguishes among different types of vendors: between those that sold poultry and game that was in season (volaillers) (fig. 3.3); boucheries, which generally only sold the best cuts of beef, veal, and lamb (fig. 3.2); those specializing in the sale of pork (charcuterie); and those that sold offal (tripiers), such as the head and tongue depicted in the Art Institute’s painting.

Elegantly arranged and hygienically presented, Caillebotte’s depictions of beef on or above the counter have little to do with the descriptions of the wholesale markets of Les Halles, which contemporary novelist Émile Zola saw as crammed, hectic, and covered in a visceral mess. As with his paintings of Parisians on display, who are “consuming” the recently developed streets of Haussmann’s Paris near the Caillebotte family home in the eighth arrondissement (see cat. 2), the artist is here showing the reality of his upper-crust world, devoted to the consumption of luxury goods, which at that time included meat.

Of the four paintings showing meat, Calf in a Butcher’s Shop (fig. 3.2) is the most elaborate, showing the calf carcass on display against a curtain and decorative wall, itself a symbol of the new means of display employed in the city’s wealthier neighborhoods. Trussed and garnished, the carcass is, as Douglas Druick pointed out, “overtly—and disturbingly—feminized, bedecked with flowers placed as if to both suggest an alluring décolletage and create a decorative border for its gaping interior.” Caillebotte scholar Michael Marrinan makes a distinction between the Art Institute’s painting and the artist’s depictions of meat in canvases such as Calf in a Butcher’s Shop (fig. 3.2), showing a store that could have been located in the neighborhood of the boulevard Haussmann, where the artist and his brother had moved in 1879. By contrast, the Art Institute painting shows the interior of a tripier, a merchant whose wares were not allowed to be sold by butchers and vendors of higher-cut meats. Marrinan suggests that the boldness of Caillebotte’s composition and palette comes from his discovery of and fascination with abats, or offal, sold in a neighborhood of very different socioeconomic status.

In the Art Institute’s still life, Caillebotte sets the highly provocative and startling pairing of an ox tongue and calf’s head against the same grayish-blue background as that in the diminutive Rib of Beef (fig. 3.1). Cleaned up, purified, and processed—with skin, hair, and fur removed—in both pictures the meat appears in a pristine and pleasing locale that belies its probable commercial setting. Marrinan has noted that Caillebotte depicts the calf’s head seen in the Art Institute’s picture after it has been blanched, rather than freshly butchered, which explains the absence of gore and its eerily pastel pinkish-white color. Despite these plausible explanations for the somewhat antiseptic way the meat is presented, the subject jars, first because it shows a head, rather than a fragment or cut of meat, and secondly because of the way it is treated by the artist. With eyelids closed, the calf’s head does not appear to be in agony; indeed, it seems not to be dead but rather in a dreamlike state. This calm submission, as if it might be sitting for a portrait, can be likened to the pig’s head “posing” for the painter in Thomas Couture’s 1865 parody of the realist artist at work, La peinture réaliste (fig. 3.5).

The jarring effect of the picture’s subject is heightened by the contrast between, on the one hand, the artist’s very plausible and practical “realist” representation of his subject and, on the other, the ease with which the unlikely pair seen in the Art Institute’s still life takes on quite different connotations. It is not difficult to see the softly curved volumetric shape of the calf’s head as existing in dialogue with the extracted tongue of the ox: its feminine form, whose gentle palette suggests soft flesh, in opposition to a fiery, muscular, elongated member that bears an irresistible resemblance to a penis. The grotesque quality of the ox tongue is mitigated by its extreme vulnerability, and, unlike the calf’s head, it appears exposed and fragile. Although we cannot know the extent to which Caillebotte was aware of this reading, in these never-exhibited canvases he was surely testing out a new subject for paintings of modern life.

By insisting on an overall bluish-lavender palette for the meat, and on a radical framing and cropping of his composition, Caillebotte further subverted the realism of seventeenth-century Dutch masters (see, for example, fig. 3.6) and the realism of contemporaries like François Bonvin and Théodule Ribot (fig. 3.7, fig. 3.8, and fig. 3.9), who both specialized in kitchen and market scenes. Despite the distancing from traditional realism that his palette implies, Caillebotte’s choices of meat are no less raw and visceral, and his renderings of his subjects are no less realist with respect to his anatomical observations. Caillebotte’s depiction of the tongue in the Art Institute painting, for example, when compared to diagrams of actual bovine anatomy, proves to be surprisingly precise. He accurately described from top to bottom the root and epiglottal area inside the throat, the bulging bend that gives it a knee-like quality, and the body of the tongue down to the red tip, which the artist painted a darker red as if rendering pooling blood. Consequently, Caillebotte’s treatment of the meat is both startlingly realistic and somewhat tempered by his preference for a pewter-blue backdrop. This treatment of his subject then can be seen to distance Caillebotte from the more traditional realism of his time, while in some way presaging the provocatively direct depictions of meat by twentieth-century artists—such as Chaim Soutine’s Carcass of Beef (fig. 3.10), Francis Bacon’s beef carcasses, and Lucian Freud’s fleshy nudes—who distanced the rawness of the subject by drawing attention instead to their bravura handling of paint and color.

This odd pairing of calf’s head and ox tongue then invites us to consider many interpretations of Caillebotte’s “realism.” Is this his bourgeois response to the slaughter, filth, and blood associated with the abattoirs of La Villette? Or is it, as Paula Young Lee has posited, a sly wink at consumption in both a gustatory and sexual sense, gesturing to the female veau (which in the nineteenth century was also a slang word for young prostitute) and the phallic male tongue? Or, as Marrinan believes, is it like all of Caillebotte’s still lifes, a testament to his engagement with a new territory, not, as in Monet’s case for monetary (easily accessible for sale) reasons, but for the purpose of artistic innovation and as an expression of his persistent penchant for arranging observed objects, be they people on the streets or fruits in a stall, throughout his career.

Although there are no known preparatory drawings or sketchbook pages related to the Art Institute’s composition, a transmitted-infrared image of the painting (fig. 3.11) suggests that Caillebotte drew in the forms broadly and made few changes to the original composition. Among these were the addition of a second calf’s head (see Application/technique and artist’s revisions in the technical report) and a slight shifting of the principal head to a more frontal position; the previous placement of the head would have revealed more of the gaping neck, which, if the animal had not been blanched, would have included a bloody gash. This area is like the rest of the composition, painted thinly and touched on lightly, almost decoratively. Equally incongruous is the artist’s treatment of the ear in the background. Although there is no evidence to show changes, it seems oddly shaped, trumpet- rather than petal-shaped like the foreground ear, with less of the latter’s delicate luminosity (fig. 3.12). The third ear and partial crown of the unseen calf’s head at far right seems to be a late addition and the major change to the original composition (see Application/technique and artist’s revisions in the technical report). It also reminds us of Caillebotte’s interest in photography: his cropping and close-up framing creates a tension that counters the traditional expectations for still lifes (which are generally accessible and literal), and alerts us to the surface patterns and the compositional decisions he is making in the name of a decorative harmony and effect. For Michael Fried the tension sensed in Calf’s Head and Ox Tongue—which for him arises from the contrast between the “brutely corporeal subject matter” and the artist’s highly refined technique—was intentional and demonstrates a continuing dichotomy between the artist’s choice of subject matter and decorative execution.

Like so many of Caillebotte’s more provocative works, including his Man at the Tub (1884; Josefowitz Collection, Lausanne [Berhaut 1978, no. 267; Berhaut 1994, no. 286]) and Nude on a Couch (1882; Minneapolis Institute of Arts [Berhaut 1978, no. 184; Berhaut 1994, no. 201]), his meat series serves up a contradiction between bourgeois propriety and Zolaesque subject, between the thing depicted and the way in which it is painted in the service of both realism and decorative unity. In Calf’s Head and Ox Tongue, he carried these contradictions to an extreme, conceiving an anthropomorphically suggestive yet graceful, decorative yet ambiguous image of offal that is imbued with multiple meanings, each of which is at the same time subverted by other meanings or aspects of the image. It is the painting’s unsettling ambiguity that makes it so modern.  
Gloria Groom

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Caillebotte began this composition on a vertically oriented standard-size, no. 20 (paysage) landscape canvas with a gray-beige commercial preparation and the imprint of the color merchant Dubus on the verso. Starting with a sketch in charcoal or black chalk, the artist laid out his composition and largely painted within the existing sketch. Changes in the composition include the placement of the butcher’s rail and its associated hooks at the bottom of the composition, the addition of the second calf’s head at the far right, and possible changes to the position of the fully visible calf’s head. The tonality of the background in the lower half of the painting was also modified from a cool, pale blue to warmer pinks and yellows. The artist varied the consistency and application of the paint to achieve a variety of textures ranging from smoothly blended to successive layers of impasto to wet-in-wet strokes with multiple colors on the brush at one time. The canvas is unlined and retains its original stretching; the painting is currently varnished.

The multilayer interactive image viewer is designed to facilitate the viewer’s exploration and comparison of the technical images (fig. 3.13).

Flax (commonly known as linen).

The original dimensions of the canvas were probably very close to the current dimensions (73 × 54.1 cm). This closely corresponds to a no. 20 landscape (paysage) standard size (73 × 54 cm), turned vertically.

Plain weave. Average thread count (standard deviation): 19.3V (0.7) × 22.0H (0.4) threads/cm. The horizontal threads were determined to correspond to the warp and the vertical threads to the weft.

The canvas shows light cusping on all sides corresponding to the placement of the original tacks. The warp-angle map (fig. 3.14) indicates that the bottom edge has very strong primary cusping associated with large-scale commercial canvas preparation. Although the canvas was not trimmed flush with the verso of the stretcher, any evidence of an unprimed edge or selvedge was probably removed from this side before or just after stretching.

Original stretching: Tacks are placed 4–8.5 cm apart. Additional, more modern tacks have been added between the original tacks.

Original stretcher: The current stretcher appears to be original. It is a five-member keyable mortise-and-tenon stretcher with a horizontal crossbar (fig. 3.15). Depth: 1.7 cm.

Stamp

Location: canvas verso  
Method: black stencil  
Content: 60 Boul<sup>d</sup> M[alesherbe]s Paris / DUBUS / COU[LEU]RS FINES & TOILES A PEINDRE / [RE]NT[OILA]GE [& R]ESTA[URATION] (fig. 3.16)

Cross-sectional analysis indicates a thin brownish layer of material between the canvas and ground that closely follows the canvas texture. This material is organic, based on its characteristic bluish fluorescence in ultraviolet light, and estimated to be glue (fig. 3.17).

The ground is a double-layer, commercial preparation that extends to the edges of the tacking margins; it appears somewhat dry and smooth in stereomicroscopic examination. The lower layer primarily fills the deepest interstices in the weave and is extremely thin along the thread tops, while the upper layer moderately fills the weave. The priming is intermittently visible along the edges of forms but was largely covered by subsequent paint layers (fig. 3.18).

The preparation is a cool gray-beige with large black and yellow particles visible in both stereomicroscopic and cross-sectional examination (fig. 3.19). The natural warmth of the ground, due to the presence of translucent materials and pigments such as iron oxide yellow in conjunction with the aging medium, combines with the darker pigment particles such that it has an almost greenish cast in certain lighting conditions (fig. 3.20).

The lower layer of the ground is largely translucent and may contain a high proportion of calcium compounds such as chalk. The upper layer of the ground is predominantly lead white with traces of iron oxide earth pigments, barium sulfate, and calcium compounds. The binder of both layers is estimated to be oil.

Stereomicroscopic examination indicates Caillebotte outlined at least the major forms in dry media before beginning to paint. Since much of this media was subsequently swept up into the paint, the full extent of the underdrawing is uncertain.

Dry media trapped under islands of paint along the edges of forms suggests the artist used charcoal or black chalk to execute the underdrawing (fig. 3.21).

There are no obvious changes to the painting in the drawing stage; however, as much of the underdrawing is either not visible or has been swept up in subsequent paint layers, the possibility of changes in this stage cannot be excluded (see Paint Layer).

The painting was executed in a limited number of wet-in-wet campaigns, often with a wide variety of colors present within a small section of the work (fig. 3.22 and fig. 3.23); the underlayers appear to have been left to dry between campaigns. The composition was largely drawn before it was painted, but small details such as the meat hooks were added on top of the finished background paint. Finally, the second calf’s head peeking in from the right edge also appears to be a late addition: blue background paint is visible amid skips in the paint layers associated with this second head (fig. 3.24).

The radio-transparent edges visible around the ox tongue and calf’s head indicate that the artist drew his composition and largely painted within the drawn lines. While it is unclear whether he began with the background, leaving the still life in reserve, or with small touches of bright color to lightly indicate the objects, Caillebotte seems to have moved back and forth between the still life and background throughout the work’s execution. The initial layers of the background, still largely visible in the top third of the composition, were thin, opaque colors applied with a stiff-bristle brush. The vigorous working of the surface—Caillebotte pressed the brush into the surface hard enough that bristles fell out and became embedded in the paint—combined with superimposed brushstrokes in different directions, and the marks left as the artist quickly lifted the brush from the surface, attest to its rapid execution (fig. 3.25). In much of the upper half of the background, the ground layer is visible amid skips and through the translucent areas where bristles scraped against the surface. In the middle and lower sections of the painting, the background is much more opaque and creamy, and appears to have been painted more than once. In the middle areas of the painting, the most opaque areas are adjacent to apparent adjustments to the outlines of the ox tongue and two calf’s heads, and smooth out the object-ground transitions. This is especially evident in the space between the two calf’s heads at right (fig. 3.26). Caillebotte varies the nature of his object-ground transition throughout the work, using a soft transition for much of the calf’s head (fig. 3.27), or adding a darker stroke of color to accentuate the border for much of the ox tongue (fig. 3.28). With the latter, the slight bleed of red lake into the background paint along the edges of the ox tongue suggests Caillebotte stopped short of creating a hard line around his object; the additional background was added while the deep red lake of the ox tongue was still very wet (fig. 3.29). The repainting of the lower third of the composition may have had more than one purpose: to cover compositional changes and to change the tonality of the background. Originally, the artist painted much cooler tones throughout the lower half so that the overall background transitioned from a darker, grayer blue to paler blue rather than the warm pinks, peaches, and yellows now visible (fig. 3.30).

Aside from the addition of the protruding ear and crown from a second calf’s head at the far right, changes to the composition appear relatively minor. The infrared and X-ray images suggest the butcher’s rail was repositioned, perhaps more than once. In the X-ray, the rail appears lower, while the infrared suggests it was once higher; it cannot be excluded that at least one of these changes was simply to narrow the rail rather than reposition it. The faintness of these features in both images suggests they were short-lived considerations. The location of the hooks along the rail was also modified, and the position of the second hook from the left was moved further to the left to accommodate the calf’s ear. The dark paint of the hooks was added wet-in-wet into the still-wet paint of the rail; the X-ray clearly shows the displacement of the rail paint by the application of the hooks (fig. 3.31). The angle of the hooks themselves appears to have been modified slightly, and traction cracks on the tips of the hooks suggests that the rail and the bases of the hooks were still soft when these features were added. Close examination of the long, linked, adjustable hook just to the left of center on the rail suggests that Caillebotte first indicated the connection between the fixed and adjustable hooks with a smaller link and simply added the larger structure around it, leaving the initial contours still visible (fig. 3.32).

While the ox tongue seems to have retained its outline, with only minor adjustments to the edges, the main calf’s head looks slightly different in many of the technical images. The X-ray and transmitted-infrared images suggest that Caillebotte added to the top of the animal’s head (above the unseen eye) so that it originally appeared much flatter; additionally, the calf’s snout was thinner. The transmitted and reflected infrared images also indicate changes to the animal’s ears—the left was larger and the right smaller. This, when combined with the flattened head, suggest the artist may have rotated the head slightly during the painting stages. A small damage is visible in the X-ray in the lower portion of the background; since the artist added opaque background paint to cover this loss, this damage probably occurred in the studio, possibly due to the removal of paint via scraping. In other areas, such as the calf’s left ear, there appears to be evidence of wiping wet paint away (fig. 3.33). Just above this area, Caillebotte dug the back of the brush into the paint but subsequently painted over this feature. As all of these features are only visible in the X-ray, they hint at further, unknown changes to the lower paint layers.

As mentioned, the painting was largely executed wet-in-wet, and Caillebotte used a variety of brushes, paint consistencies, and blending techniques—as well as a variety of strokes—to add texture and depth to the work. The background, as mentioned, utilizes opaque paint of varying consistencies, a stiff-bristle brush, and multidirectional and crosshatching brushwork, resulting in a mottled appearance. The calf’s head is largely blended with soft, fine brushes and directional strokes (fig. 3.34); toward the end of the process, the artist added touches of bright color such as the orange above the eyelid (fig. 3.35). The calf’s ears and the inside of the neck are rendered in thicker, more pastel-like paint, with darker, more saturated colors and less blending (fig. 3.36). The edge of the calf’s right ear has a strange comb-like texture, possibly caused by a scraping tool or a brush caked with dry paint (fig. 3.37). Each area of the ox tongue is handled individually, with short, directional, relatively unblended strokes and a fine brush for the tongue itself; here the artist often picked up two or more premixed colors onto his brush at one time. In the body of the tongue, the directional strokes are punctuated with short dashes from a brush with both blue and dark red paint (fig. 3.38), and an almost crusty impasto was employed for the orange and blue highlights near the back of the tongue (fig. 3.39). The root, back of the throat, and base of the skull are all painted very thickly with a wide variety of saturated colors. In several areas, the bright reds and deep reds near the edges of these forms were augmented and applied over the background (fig. 3.40). In some areas, the increased blending with each stroke of a new color cutting into the still-wet color beneath is readily visible (fig. 3.41). In others, the variety of colors present in a single stroke is clearly apparent (fig. 3.42). In many areas, there is a textural contrast between paint applied over dry strokes, where it catches and reinforces only the high points of the underlying texture, and wet-in-wet applications where paint of varying consistency is set into, cut into, and swept across still-wet paint. No matter the type of application, in many areas, the brightest strokes appear to be the final touches (fig. 3.43).

Primarily fine flat- and round-ferrule brushes with strokes up to 0.6 cm wide throughout the ox tongue, calf’s head, and butcher’s rail; isolated areas of wider strokes, up to 1 cm wide, in the background.

XRF analysis suggests the presence of the following pigments: lead white, cadmium yellow, iron oxide yellow and/or red, vermilion, emerald green, chromium-containing pigments such as viridian, and cobalt blue.

UV examination suggests the presence of fluorescing red lake in several areas of the painting, including the fleshy protrusions on either side of the ox tongue (associated with the root of the tongue and the base of the throat), based on the observation of characteristic salmon-colored fluorescence (fig. 3.44). Visual examination suggests there is a second, non-fluorescing red lake in other areas, such as the tip of the tongue and throughout the pale pinks of both the tongue and the calf’s head.

Oil (estimated).

The painting has an overall synthetic varnish that is not original to the painting. The lack of discolored natural-resin varnish in the depressions of the paint layer or evidence of previous cleaning, such as solvent penetration through the cracks to the canvas verso, suggests the painting was originally unvarnished.

Additional tacks were added along the tacking margins (between the original tacks), the keys were secured with paper tape, and the painting was lightly varnished in an undocumented treatment prior to acquisition. UV and stereomicroscopic examination suggest there was no retouching associated with this treatment.

The painting is in very good condition, unlined, and varnished. It is planar and retains its original stretcher and original stretching; additional tacks have been added between the original tacks for supplemental support. The corners of the stretcher are slightly out of alignment—the ends of the vertical members are proud of the horizontal members at all four corners; these are areas of additional stress, abrasion, wear, and minor tearing. There are dark rubs and some abrasion from the frame rebate around the perimeter. As noted elsewhere (see Paint Layer), a small damage visible in the X-ray appears to have occurred in the artist’s studio and was painted out with additional background paint. There is mild cracking through areas of impasto, localized wrinkling and drying crackle, a stretcher-bar crack on the right side, and a scratch in the upper left corner. There are localized accretions and brush inclusions throughout. There is no apparent retouching and there are no major losses.  
Kelly Keegan

Current frame (installed 1999): The current frame is not original to the painting. It is a French, nineteenth-century, plain molding scotia frame. The frame has water gilding over red bole. The outer treacle and inner fillet are burnished; the scotia and ogee sight molding have matte gilding. The frame retains its original gilding and glue sizing. The sides have been painted with buff-colored casein paint. The pine molding is mitered and joined with angled, sliding, dovetailed splines and has an independent half-lapped back frame. The molding, from the perimeter to the interior, is scotia side; treacle molding ended high by a fillet on the outside edge; fillet; scotia; astragal; fillet; and ogee sight edge (fig. 3.45).

Previous frame (installed by 1994, removed by 1999): The painting was previously housed in what appears to be a Louis XIII convex frame with stylized acanthus-leaf ornament. The frame had water gilding with a burnished hollow and ornament. The molding, from the perimeter to the interior, was side unknown; convex with stylized acanthus-leaf ornament and acanthus leaves at the miters; fillet; hollow frieze; fillet; and ogee with leaf-tip ornament at the sight edge (fig. 3.46).  
Kirk Vuillemot

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Calf’s Head and Ox Tongue (Berhaut 1978, no. 222; Berhaut 1994, no. 244) corresponds to the Caillebotte catalogues raisonnés: Berhaut 1978, p. 156, cat. 222 (ill.); and Berhaut 1994, p. 165, cat. 244 (ill.). The Art Institute currently uses a title that is based on the title given to the painting when it was exhibited in the 1894 exhibition Exposition rétrospective d’oeuvres de G. Caillebotte, held at Galeries Durand-Ruel.

The Art Institute currently uses the date that is used by the Caillebotte catalogues raisonnés. See Berhaut 1978, p. 156, cat. 222 (ill.); and Berhaut 1994, p. 165, cat. 244 (ill.). Anne Distel has suggested that this work and other still-life paintings currently dated by Marie Berhaut in her 1994 catalogue raisonné as circa 1882 might have been conceived three years later, in 1885, citing commentary from Félix Fénéon included in Les impressionnists en 1886. Anne Distel to Gloria Groom, Mar. 10, 2015, e-mail correspondence, curatorial object file, Art Institute of Chicago. Fénéon contrasts Caillebotte’s earlier depictions, the vast compositions and paintings of bourgeois life, with simpler compositions such as Calf’s Head: “Parmi les Caillebotte de 1885–1886, plus de ces vastes compositions, vues en 1880 et en 1882, où se reconstitue la vie de la bourgeois parisienne, mais des oeuvres de fabrication moins ardue: des paysages d’Argenteuil, des natures mortes, —langoustes, poissons, viandes, lièvres, huîtres, bouteilles, un veau au croc s’ouvrant blanc dans l’ovale guirlande de fleurs qui l’ourle.” Félix Fénéon, Oeuvres plus que complètes, vol. 1, ed. Joan U. Halperin (Librairie Droz, 1970), p. 45. But the fact that Fénéon mentions works done in the past, and cites the entire series of still lifes, including images of rabbits (but not poultry, which were also included in an earlier work), may also simply reflect the fact that Caillebotte, for whom money was not a concern, had kept the works in his studio until 1886, when Fénéon saw them and felt compelled to mention them in his review of the 1886 exhibition. Distel further notes that Martial, Caillebotte’s brother, does not seem to have remembered the exact date of this painting, leaving out the last numeral for the date “[188]” in the caption on a photograph identifying Tête de veau. I am grateful to Anne Distel for the Fénéon reference, which deserves further research. For the still-life pictures dated to circa 1882, see Berhaut 1994, pp. 163–67.

See also Berhaut 1994, pp. 164, cat. 242; 165, cats. 243–45. As noted, Calf’s Head and Ox Tongue is the only one of the four that does not bear an estate stamp.

See Joris-Karl Huysmans, “Appendice,” L’art moderne (G. Charpentier, 1883). Excerpt translated in Eliza E. Rathbone and George T. M. Shackelford, Impressionist Still Life, exh. cat. (Phillips Collection/Abrams, 2001), p. 136.

Anne Distel has suggested that these paintings might have been conceived three years later in 1885, citing Félix Fénéon’s commentary in Les impressionnistes en 1886. See Anne Distel to Gloria Groom, Mar. 10, 2015, e-mail correspondence, curatorial object file, Art Institute of Chicago. Fénéon contrasts Caillebotte’s earlier depictions, the vast compositions and paintings of bourgeois life, with the simpler compositions: “Parmi les Caillebotte de 1885–1886, plus de ces vastes compositions, vues en 1880 et en 1882, où se reconstitue la vie de la bourgeoisie parisienne, mais des oeuvres de fabrication moins ardue: des paysages d’Argenteuil, des natures mortes—langoustes, poissons, viandes, lièvres, huîtres, bouteilles, un veau au croc s’ouvrant blanc dans l’ovale guirlande de fleurs qui l’ourle.” See Félix Fénéon, Oeuvres plus que complètes, vol. 1, ed. Joan U. Halperin (Librairie Droz, 1970), p. 45. But the fact that Fénéon mentions works done in the past and cites the entire series of still lifes, including images of rabbits (but not poultry, which were also included in an earlier work), may also simply reflect the fact that Caillebotte, for whom money was not a concern, had kept the works in his studio until 1886, when Fénéon saw them and felt compelled to mention them in his review of the 1886 exhibition. Distel further notes that Martial, Caillebotte’s brother, does not seem to have remembered the exact date of this painting, leaving out the last numeral for the date “[188]” in the caption on a photograph identifying Tête de Veau. I am grateful to Anne Distel for the Fénéon reference, which deserves further research. For the still-life pictures dated to c. 1882, see Berhaut 1994, pp. 163–67.

See Joris-Karl Huysmans, “Appendice,” L’art moderne (G. Charpentier, 1883): “ses fruits se détachant sur des lits de papier blanc sont extraordinaires . . . c’est d’une stricte vérité, d’une fidélité absolue de tons; c’est la nature morte exonérée de sa dîme routinière.” Excerpt translated in Eliza E. Rathbone and George T. M. Shackelford, Impressionist Still Life, exh. cat. (Phillips Collection/Abrams, 2001), p. 136.

See Joris-Karl Huysmans, “Appendice,” L’art moderne (G. Charpentier, 1883), cited in Douglas Druick, “Still Lifes,” in Anne Distel, Douglas Druick, Gloria Groom, Rodolphe Rapetti, with Julia Sagraves and an essay by Kirk Varnedoe, Gustave Caillebotte: Urban Impressionist, exh. cat. (Musée d’Orsay/Art Institute of Chicago, 1995), p. 244.

See Joris-Karl Huysmans, “Appendice,” L’art moderne (G. Charpentier, 1883), as cited in Douglas Druick, “Still Lifes,” in Anne Distel, Douglas Druick, Gloria Groom, Rodolphe Rapetti, with Julia Sagraves and an essay by Kirk Varnedoe, Gustave Caillebotte: Urban Impressionist, exh. cat. (Musée d’Orsay/Art Institute of Chicago, 1995), p. 244. See Eliza E. Rathbone and George T. M. Shackelford, Impressionist Still Life, exh. cat. (Phillips Collection/Abrams, 2001), p. 136; and Ruth E. Iskin, Modern Women and Parisian Consumer Culture in Impressionist Painting (Cambridge University Press, 2007), p. 176, who both suggest that the white paper and greenery indicate the display of a high-class grocer.

See Anne Distel to Gloria Groom, Mar. 10, 2015, e-mail correspondence, curatorial object file, Art Institute of Chicago, in which Distel explains that there is a distinction to be made between different purveyors of meat in Paris.

For the dramatic contrast between the dirty wholesale markets and the more upscale neighborhood markets suggested by Caillebotte’s depictions, see Ruth E. Iskin, Modern Women and Parisian Consumer Culture in Impressionist Painting (Cambridge University Press, 2007), pp. 148–54, 172–79. Both she and Douglas Druick cite the description of the vast, dark, and grime-filled wholesale markets at Les Halles that were chronicled in Émile Zola’s 1873 novel Le ventre de Paris. See also Douglas Druick, “Still Lifes,” in Anne Distel, Douglas Druick, Gloria Groom, Rodolphe Rapetti, with Julia Sagraves and an essay by Kirk Varnedoe, Gustave Caillebotte: Urban Impressionist, exh. cat. (Musée d’Orsay/Art Institute of Chicago, 1995), pp. 235, 244.

Meat in general was out of reach for the very poor. See Karin Sagner, “Gustave Caillebotte: An Impressionist and Photography,” in Gustave Caillebotte: An Impressionist and Photography, ed. Karin Sagner and Max Hollein, in cooperation with Ulrich Pohlmann, exh. cat. (Schirn Kunsthalle Frankfurt/Hirmer, 2012), pp. 29–30, who indicates that “By the end of the nineteenth century, meat had displaced bread as the staff of life, but for the working class, it was too expensive and present only in their imagination and as an enticement.”

According to Ruth E. Iskin, Modern Women and Parisian Consumer Culture in Impressionist Painting (Cambridge University Press, 2007), p. 152: “The shop window is a miniature version of the new world order of Parisian consumer culture represented through the ornamental display of goods.” Michael Marrinan’s forthcoming book on Caillebotte (Gustave Caillebotte: A Painter in Paris, 1872–1887 [Getty Research Institute]) describes the situation for butcher shops in Paris, which were carefully regulated and which involved special architectural treatments that would allow for circulation of air in an era before refrigeration was widespread. I am grateful to Dr. Marrinan for pointing out that butcher shops would not have been allowed to have plate glass in the 1880s; see Michael Marrinan to Gloria Groom, Apr. 26, 2015, e-mail correspondence, curatorial object file, Art Institute of Chicago.

Douglas Druick, “Still Lifes,” in Anne Distel, Douglas Druick, Gloria Groom, Rodolphe Rapetti, with Julia Sagraves and an essay by Kirk Varnedoe, Gustave Caillebotte: Urban Impressionist, exh. cat. (Musée d’Orsay/Art Institute of Chicago, 1995), p. 248.

Éric Darragon, Gustave Caillebotte, trans. Marie-Hélène Agüros (Bonfini, 1994), p. 103, believes Calf’s Head and Ox Tongue to be displayed at a stand in a tripe shop. It is possible that Caillebotte’s tripe shop (tripier) was located near the rue Vintimille in the Batignolles neighborhood, where he had a studio at number 20 at least until spring 1882. See Anne Distel, “Chronology,” in Anne Distel, Douglas Druick, Gloria Groom, Rodolphe Rapetti, with Julia Sagraves and an essay by Kirk Varnedoe, Gustave Caillebotte: Urban Impressionist, exh. cat. (Musée d’Orsay/Art Institute of Chicago, 1995), p. 316.

See Michael Marrinan, “Commerce,” in Gustave Caillebotte: A Painter in Paris, 1872–1887 (Getty Research Institiute, forthcoming): “When Caillebotte ventures into the world of abats and triperies, he leaves behind a familiar world of the upper bourgeoisie to enter the land of low-cost meats and vulgar tastes. The shock and surprise—perhaps even delight—he finds there is registered in the picture as an overly vivid, gripping hallucination.” My deepest thanks to Dr. Marrinan for providing me with an advance copy of this chapter.

Michael Marrinan’s extensive study of this painting notes that the contrasting white-and-red palette was aligned with the two types of material sold in a triperie: red (sold raw) and white (blanched before sale), explaining also the lack of “gore” in the calf’s head. See Michael Marrinan, “Commerce,” in Gustave Caillebotte: A Painter in Paris, 1872–1887 (Getty Research Institute, forthcoming). See also L. Baillet, “Altérations des viandes,” in Traité de l’inspection des viandes de boucherie (Librairies de la Faculté de Medicine, 1880), pp. 460–61.

I am grateful to Paula Young Lee for sending me an advance offprint of her essay “Stripped: Gustave Caillebotte and the Carcass of Modern Life,” in Visions of the Industrial Age, 1830–1914: Modernity and the Anxiety of Representation in Europe, ed. Minsoo Kang and Amy Woodson-Boulton (Ashgate, 2008), p. 287: “The resemblance helps imbue the long, thin, flattened, slightly bent and pointed configuration of that red-tipped tongue with something of the grotesque, for it is dangling and impotent, challenging the viewer to view this most eloquent of organs as a mute and powerless object.” See also Karin Sagner, “Gustave Caillebotte: An Impressionist and Photography,” in Gustave Caillebotte: An Impressionist and Photography, ed. Karin Sagner and Max Hollein, in cooperation with Ulrich Pohlmann, exh. cat. (Schirn Kunsthalle Frankfurt/Hirmer, 2012), p. 30.

See Klaus-Dieter Budras and Robert E. Habel, Bovine Anatomy (Schlütersche, 2003), pp. 44–46. See also Dr. Julie A. McGwin, Veterinarian Specialist Senior/Program Manager, Wisconsin Department of Agriculture, Trade, and Consumer Protection, to Genevieve Westerby, May 13, 2015, e-mail correspondence, curatorial object file, Art Institute of Chicago. Dr. McGwin was able to confirm the veracity of Caillebotte’s depiction of an ox tongue.

My thanks to Dr. Julie A. McGwin, Veterinarian Specialist Senior/Program Manager, Wisconsin Department of Agriculture, Trade, and Consumer Protection, for her expertise and assistance. Dr. McGwin further identified the shield-like shape above the tongue, into which the hook was inserted, as being formed by the stylohyoid bone. See Julie A. McGwin to Genevieve Westerby, May 13, 2015, e-mail correspondence, curatorial object file, Art Institute of Chicago. See also Klaus-Dieter Budras and Robert E. Habel, Bovine Anatomy (Schlütersche, 2003), pp. 44–46.

In addition to the meat pictures, Caillebotte employed a silvery-blue backdrop in several portraits completed around this time. See, for example, Intérieur, femme lisant (1880 [Berhaut 1978, no. 127; Berhaut 1994, no. 139]) and La femme à la rose (1884 [Berhaut 1978, no. 262; Berhaut 1994, no. 287]). See also other still-life compositions from this period, such as Yellow Roses in a Vase (1882 [Berhaut 1978, no. 206; Berhaut 1994, no. 240]), which depicts a vase of flowers placed on a marbled blue-gray surface very similar to that seen in Rib of Beef (fig. 3.1).

See Stephen F. Eisenman, The Cry of Nature: Art and the Making of Animal Rights (Reaktion, 2013), pp. 171–72. La Villette, also known as the “City of Blood,” was a centralized complex of slaughterhouses that opened in 1867 and was located “far from the other Paris of new grand boulevards and gilded facades, where the fashionable Parisian bourgeoisie passed their days and nights.” See Kyri Claflin, “La Villette: City of Blood (1867–1914),” in Meat, Modernity, and the Rise of the Slaughterhouse, ed. Paula Young Lee (University of New Hampshire Press/University Press of New England, 2008), p. 29.

Lee proposes that Caillebotte would have known of the alternate meanings for the word veau and that his four works of meat on display provide a veiled but knowing comment on the parallels between the marketplace (for meat produce) and the market for purchasable sex. See Paula Young Lee, “Stripped: Gustave Caillebotte and the Carcass of Modern Life,” in Visions of the Industrial Age, 1830–1914: Modernity and the Anxiety of Representation in Europe, ed. Minsoo Kang and Amy Woodson-Boulton (Ashgate, 2008), pp. 278, 287–88.

Stereomicroscopic examination revealed small clusters of dark underdrawing material, possibly charcoal, trapped under islands of paint. See Compositional Planning in the Technical Report.

Michael Fried, “Caillebotte’s Impressionism,” Representations 66 (Spring 1999), pp. 34–36.

Using the toolbar at the bottom right, any two images of the painting may be selected for comparison by clicking the layers icon to the right of the slider bar. The slider bar may be moved to transition back and forth between the two chosen images. The jagged line icon brings up a list of available annotations, or colored lines that show the significant features visible in each image, which may be turned on or off in any combination. For example, the red annotation lines, associated with the natural-light image, trace some of the painting’s key compositional features. When overlaid onto a technical image (X-ray, raking light, UV, etc.), the red outlines help the viewer to better observe how features in the technical image relate to or diverge from the painting as seen with the naked eye. (When annotations are turned on, a legend appears in the upper right showing each color and its associated image type.) The circular arrow icon returns the image to the default settings (natural light, full-image view, natural-light [red] annotation on). The four-arrow icon toggles between the view of the image in the page and a full-screen view of the image. In the upper-right corner, the vertical slider bar may be moved to zoom into or out of the image; different parts of the image can be accessed by clicking and dragging within the image itself. The icon in the upper-left corner opens a small view of the full image, within which a red box indicates the portion of the overall image being viewed when zooming is enabled.

Flax was confirmed by microscopic cross-sectional fiber identification; see Inge Fiedler, “1999\_561\_Caill\_calfs\_head\_analytical\_report,” May 19, 2015, on file in the Conservation Department, Art Institute of Chicago.

See chart of standard sizes available from Bourgeois Aîné in 1888, reproduced in David Bomford, Jo Kirby, John Leighton, and Ashok Roy, Art in the Making: Impressionism, exh. cat. (National Gallery, London/Yale University Press, 1990), p. 46, fig. 31.

Thread count and weave information were determined by Thread Count Automation Project software. See Don H. Johnson, and Robert G. Erdmann, “Thread Count Report: Gustave Caillebotte, Calf’s Head and Ox Tongue (B244/1999.561),” Dec. 2014.

Strong cusping along a single side of a canvas generally indicates that it came from the edge of a larger section of canvas (one–two meters wide by five–ten meters long) that was commercially prepared and later cut down to make smaller canvases. For a discussion of commercial canvas preparation, see David Bomford, Jo Kirby, John Leighton, and Ashok Roy, Art in the Making: Impressionism, exh. cat. (National Gallery, London/Yale University Press, 1990), p. 46; Iris Schaefer, Caroline von Saint-George, and Katja Lewerentz, Painting Light: The Hidden Techniques of the Impressionists (Skira, 2008), p. 52. Thread-angle maps were produced with Thread Count Automation Project software. See Don H. Johnson and Robert G. Erdmann, “Thread Count Report: Gustave Caillebotte, Calf’s Head and Ox Tongue (B244/1999.561),” Dec. 2014.

Although often called a “stamp,” it is clear that this particular mark was applied as a spray over a stencil; close examination of the color merchant’s mark on the back of the canvas reveals the faint square edges of the stencil from this publication (surrounded by a shadow of dark overspray) used to apply it. This stamp for the color merchant Dubus was also found on four paintings by Caillebotte in the Wallraf-Richartz collection: The Plain of Gennevilliers, Yellow Fields (1884), Hills at Colombes (1890), Branch of the Seine, Autumn Atmosphere (1890), and Regatta at Argenteuil (1893). See corresponding entries for each painting by Caroline von Saint-George and Katja Lewerentz in Painting Techniques of Impressionism and Postimpressionism (Wallraf-Richartz-Museum & Fondation Corboud, 2008), http://www.museenkoeln.de/impressionismus; for a detailed graphic description of the Dubus stencil, see Caroline von Saint-George and Katja Lewerentz, “Gustave Caillebotte–Arm of the Seine, Autumnal Mood: Brief report on Technology and Condition,” p. 9.

The cross section sample from the edge of the tacking margin contained all preparatory layers and the canvas. See Inge Fiedler, “1999\_561\_Caill\_calfs\_head\_analytical\_report,” May 19, 2015, on file in the Conservation Department, Art Institute of Chicago.

The ground composition was analyzed using XRF. For more detailed results and conditions used, see Kim Muir, “Cai­\_CalfsHd\_99\_561\_XRF\_Results,” Dec. 4, 2014, on file in the Conservation Department, Art Institute of Chicago.

The binding medium was not analyzed. The estimation of an oil medium is based on visual examination as well as on knowledge of Caillebotte’s technique.

Kim Muir, “Cai­\_CalfsHd\_99\_561\_XRF\_Results,” Dec. 4, 2014, on file in the Conservation Department, Art Institute of Chicago. XRF analysis was carried out in air. XRF does not detect organic pigments, if present, and has low sensitivity for elements like silicon and sodium (a component of ultramarine blue). Analysis was carried out on selected areas and may not include all pigments present.

Identifying the specific type of lake used only by its fluorescence under UV is difficult, as many factors, including the type of mordant, binders, varnishes, and admixtures with other pigments can ultimately affect the perceived color of the fluorescence. Some types of madder and purpurin lake pigments have been reported to fluoresce orange, but other lakes, such as lacs, may fluoresce as well. The characteristics of red lake, including its fluorescence under ultraviolet light, are discussed in Helmut Schweppe and John Winter, “Madder and Alizarin,” in Artists’ Pigments: A Handbook of Their History and Characteristics, vol. 3, ed. Elizabeth West FitzHugh (National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C., 1997), pp. 124–26. See also Ruth Johnston-Feller, Color Science in the Examination of Museum Objects: Nondestructive Procedures (Getty Conservation Institute, 2001), p. 207.

The binding medium was not analyzed. The estimation of an oil medium is based on visual examination as well as on knowledge of Caillebotte’s technique.

According to Berhaut 1994, p. 165, cat. 244 (ill.). A photocopy of an annotated exhibition catalogue in the curatorial object file, Art Institute of Chicago, includes a price annotation that is illegible due to a tear in the original catalogue. For more on the 1894 exhibition, see Anne Distel, “Introduction: Caillebotte as Painter, Benefactor, and Collector,” in Anne Distel, Douglas Druick, Gloria Groom, and Rodolphe Rapetti, with Julia Sagraves and an essay by Kirk Varnedoe, Gustave Caillebotte: Urban Impressionist, exh. cat. (Musée d’Orsay/Art Institute of Chicago, 1995), pp. 24; 26, n. 49.

This catalogue was reprinted as Theodore Reff, ed., Exhibitions of Impressionist Art 2, Modern Art in Paris 44 (Garland, 1981), n. pag.

Translated by Marie-Hélène Agüros as Gustave Caillebotte (Bonfini, 1994), p. 104 (ill.).

Reprinted as Michael Fried, “Caillebotte’s Impressionism,” in Gustave Caillebotte and the Fashioning of Identity in Impressionist Paris, ed. Norma Broude (Rutgers University Press, 2002), pp. 98; 99, fig. 36; 102; and Fried, Another Light: Jacques-Louis David to Thomas Demand (Yale University Press, 2014), pp. 185–86, fig. 139 (ill.).

The latter was republished as Gloria Groom and Douglas Druick, with the assistance of Dorota Chudzicka and Jill Shaw, The Age of French Impressionism: Masterpieces from the Art Institute of Chicago, rev. and expanded ed. (Art Institute of Chicago/Yale University Press, 2010; repr. 2013), pp. 92–93, cat. 43 (ill.).

A supplement to the catalogue was simultaneously published in conjunction with the Gemeentemuseumm de Haag. See Karin Sagner, “Gustave Caillebotte: Een Impressionist en de fotografie,” in Karin Sagner, Ulrich Pohlmann, Franz Kaiser, and Gilles Chardeau, with a foreword by Benno Tempel, Gustave Caillebotte: Een impressionist en de fotografie (Gemeentemuseum den Haag, 2013), pp. 19, 30 (ill.).

See Damon M. Conover, John K. Delaney, Paola Ricciardi, and Murray H. Loew, “Towards Automatic Registration of Technical Images of Works of Art,” in Computer Vision and Image Analysis of Art II, ed. David G. Stork, James Coddington, and Anna Bentkowska-Kafel, Proc. SPIE 7869 (SPIE/IS&T, 2011); doi:10.1117/12.872634.
